Pawn or pledge means a bailment of personal property or title (including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle title) as security for any debt or engagement, redeemable upon certain terms and with the express or implied power of sale on default. 
Pawn transaction means any loan on the security of pledged goods or any purchase of pledged goods on the condition that the pledged goods may be redeemed or repurchased by the pledger or seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time. 
Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, personal property or titles, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property or title on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property or title from persons or sources other than the manufacturers or regulated dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described herein. 
Pawnshop means any business wherein a well-defined part of such business is to take or receive, by way of pledge, pawn, or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise, motor vehicles, or any kind of personal property or title whatsoever, as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-114. - Violation of article. 
(a)  In addition to the licensee, any person violating any of the provisions of this article may be cited and shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in the general penalties described in section 1-12. 
(b)  The licensee(s) shall be responsible for violations of this article. 
(c)  The violation of the provisions of this article by any person may be enjoined by instituting appropriate proceedings for injunction in the courts of competent jurisdiction of this state. Such actions may be maintained, notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law may exist. Such actions may be instituted in the name of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-115. - Applications; contents; deadline for submission; fees. 
(a)  Any person(s) desiring to obtain a license required under this article shall make written application to the city manager through the city clerk for such privilege upon forms to be prepared and approved by the city. Such application shall require the name, address, telephone number, and email address of the applicant and the proposed licensee, if different than the applicant and a description of the nature and character of the business to be conducted. If the applicant or the proposed licensee is a partnership, the applicant must provide with the application the names, addresses, telephone numbers, and email addresses of all partners. If the applicant or the proposed licensee is a corporation, the applicant must provide with the application the names, addresses, telephone numbers, and email addresses of the officers and stockholders with 20 percent or more ownership. 
(b)  At the time application is made, the applicant, on behalf of the proposed licensee, shall designate the person to be responsible for acceptance of service of any process, notice, violation, or demand required or permitted by law or under this chapter. 
(c)  In addition to the foregoing, the city may require additional information to assist it in evaluating the request for a license. No application shall be completed and submitted by anyone under the age of 21. 
(d)  Applicants shall furnish all data, information, and records reasonably requested of them by the city and failure to furnish such data, information and records within 30 days from the date of such request shall be considered abandonment of the application. 
(e)  At the time of application, the applicant shall certify for himself/herself and as the representative of the proposed licensee that they have read this article and agree to comply with its requirements. If the license is granted, each licensee shall maintain a copy of this article on the premises. 
(f)  The application shall be made on an annual basis. 
(g)  Licensees shall immediately notify the city in writing through the city clerk of any change in any information, material or data furnished in connection with an application for a license, or of any material change in the type of business, ownership or qualifications of any licensee, applicant, or employee subsequent to license issuance. 
(h)  The initial license application shall be accompanied by an application fee in the amount of $100.00. Subsequent renewal applications shall be accompanied by a $50.00 renewal application fee. Application fees are not subject to refund. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-116. - Investigation of applicant; report by police department. 
Accompanying submission of all applications to the city as required by this article shall be executed consent forms authorizing the city to conduct background investigations, including criminal background investigations on each individual having an interest in the license. For the purpose of this section, in reference to corporations, consent forms will be initially required for stockholders that have at least 20 percent ownership in stock shares. All applications shall be investigated, and the police department shall provide its findings to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-117. - Issuance to persons with prior convictions prohibited; exception; pending. 
No license under this article shall be issued where any individual having an interest in the license shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony, misdemeanor or offense of any state or of the United States or any municipal or county ordinance related to moral turpitude, illegal gambling, theft, deception or fraudulent practices. For purposes of this article, a conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere entered under the Georgia First Offender Act, O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq., shall not be considered. Provided, however, that any such offense shall be considered and be deemed disqualifying where the applicant violated any term of probation imposed by the court granting first offender status or committed another crime and the sentencing court entered an adjudication of guilt as to the crime for which the defendant had previously been sentenced as a first offender. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime. Where the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of bond, or violation of a municipal or county ordinance, the city council may, upon denial on such a basis and upon appeal, consider waiving such violation as a disqualification. No license shall be issued so long as there are outstanding criminal warrants, criminal charges, accusations or indictments for any of the crimes enumerated in this section on which there has been no final disposition or adjudication, and any application involving such pending charges shall be held for final decision until final disposition or adjudication of the charges. No license to operate a pawnshop that deals in firearms shall be issued to any convicted felon, unless that person's right to possess firearms has been verifiably reinstated in the jurisdiction where the conviction occurred. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-118. - Disqualification of applicant(s); licensees. 
No license under this article shall be granted where the application or the evidence shows any of the following conditions to exist: 
(1)  An applicant or proposed licensee has had any pawnbroker license issued by a municipality, county, or other governmental entity previously suspended or revoked. 
(2)  An applicant or proposed licensee, while a holder of a previous license to operate a pawnshop in any jurisdiction, has been convicted of violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business, within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of application, or, within the same time period, has any disqualifying conviction under section 12-117. 
(3)  An applicant or proposed licensee has failed to comply with any other requirements of any local, state, or federal law prescribed for the operation of the business contemplated by the license sought. 
(4)  An applicant or proposed licensee has supplied false information either upon his application or in any communication with any official of the city relative to his application. 
(5)  An applicant or proposed licensee has failed to pay any fee due to the city or county or has otherwise failed to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(6)  An applicant or proposed licensee, during the 12-month period immediately preceding the filing of his application, has been determined by a competent court or administrative agency of having engaged in a deceptive business practice. 
(7)  In addition to subsections (1) through (6) of this section and in determining whether or not any license applied for shall be granted, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: 
a.  If any applicant or proposed licensee is a previous holder of a license, the manner in which he conducted the business under such license as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. 
b.  The location for which the license is sought as to traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values. 
c.  The number of licenses already granted for similar businesses in the trading area of and the place for which that license is sought. 
d.  Whether and the extent to which the applicant or proposed licensee is presented as or engaged in a ruse or scheme to procure a license for a person or entity not otherwise eligible for a license. 
(8)  No more than five such business establishments are permissible within the city; provided, however, that if such a business establishment ceases operation, the maximum number of such permissible business establishments within the city is reduced correspondingly, and no additional business establishment is permissible if the number of such business establishments then in operation exceeds a threshold of one such licensed business establishment for each 2,000 citizens in the city plus one additional license for any fractional figure exceeding the 2,000 citizen population threshold. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-119. - Consideration by city manager. 
(a)  If the background investigation, including the criminal investigation, do not disclose disqualifying information or any other information requiring denial of the license and all other requirements for licensing are satisfied, then the city manager shall issue the license. 
(b)  If the city manager determines that the license should be denied, then the city manager shall inform the proposed licensee, in writing, that the application is denied, providing a description in reasonable detail of the reasons for the denial and notifying the proposed licensee of the right to appeal. 
(c)  Such appeal shall be before the city council in accordance with section 12-120 of this article. An appeal must be requested in writing and must be filed with the city clerk within ten business days of the date of the denial notice. An appeal shall be scheduled for a hearing before the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting, provided that such meeting is no less than 15 days from the date the written request for an appeal is filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-120. - Appeal hearings. 
(a)  Written notice of date, time, and place of the hearing on an appeal of denial of a license shall be provided to the proposed licensee, provided that the proposed licensee shall be provided no less than 15 days' notice of the hearing. 
(b)  At the hearing, the proposed licensee shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard and to present evidence, including witness testimony, in support of any contention that the denial is unwarranted or is otherwise inconsistent with the requirements of this article or any other provision of law. The proposed licensee is entitled to be represented by counsel at the hearing who may argue for and present the case of the proposed licensee. 
(c)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the city council shall determine whether to sustain the decision of the city manager, reverse the decision of the city manager, or reverse the decision of the city manager but imposing conditions to be satisfied by the proposed licensee. The decision of the city council is final, subject to appeal to the Superior Court of Paulding County by way of a petition for a writ of certiorari as provided in O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-121. - Revocation and suspension of licenses—Generally. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of this section, the city manager may, for due cause, suspend, revoke, or place on probation, with or without conditions, any license issued under this article. 
(b)  Due cause for the revocation, suspension, or imposition of probationary status shall consist of any of the following: 
(1)  A licensee commits a deceptive business practice that consists of: 
a.  Using or possessing a false weight or measure, or any other device for falsely determining or recording any quality or quantity in connection with any sale or service; 
b.  Selling, offering, exposing for sale, or delivering less than the represented quality or quantity; 
c.  Taking or attempting to take more than the represented quantity of any commodity when as buyer or broker the licensee furnishes the weight or measure; 
d.  Providing a service which is of any unreasonably lesser quality than the service offered or represented; 
e.  Engaging in any other fraudulent business transaction which is made punishable by the laws of the state; 
f.  Commission of any of the foregoing by any person employed or otherwise utilized in transacting the business of the licensee; or 
g.  Any misrepresentation of fact, whether through advertisement or through any form of direct communication, oral or written, which is intended to mislead the public or to mislead any party with whom the licensee deals in pursuance of the licensee's business. The term "misrepresentation of fact," as used in this subsection, shall embrace not only express misrepresentations but also misrepresentations arising by virtue of the licensee's conduct, including acts and omissions. 
(2)  Violation of any laws, ordinances, or resolutions regulating such business, or violation of regulations made pursuant to the authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business. 
(3)  Providing false information to the city in support of the application for a license or any renewal thereof or in response to any of the reporting requirements imposed by this article, regardless of when the city shall have become aware of such false information. 
(4)  Failure to comply with any other requirements of any local, state, or federal law prescribed for the operation of the business contemplated by the license sought as well as any other local, state, or federal law applicable to the business operation, including, but not limited to, the acts or practices declared unlawful by the State Fair Business Practices Act of 1975 (O.C.G.A. § 10-1-390 et seq.), as it may be amended from time to time or declared unlawful by the administrator of the Act pursuant to regulations issued under Section 4 of the Act, all subject to the exemptions in Section 6 of the Act. 
(5)  Failing to comply with any provisions of this article. 
(6)  The licensee has lost qualifications required by this article. 
(c)  Upon determining that a license issued under this article should be suspended, revoked or placed on probation with or without conditions, the city manager shall inform the licensee in writing of that tentative decision and provide a description of the reason(s) why the action should be taken. The licensee shall be given seven business days to meet with the city manager to review and consider the situation, including the action proposed by the city manager. The licensee will be informed in writing of the city manager's final action within three business days of such meeting. The writing shall describe the reason(s) for the city manager's action(s) and notify the licensee of a right to appeal the action to the city council. A licensee's failure to meet with the city manager within the seven-day window constitutes a waiver of the right to so meet and any rights attendant to such a meeting and the notice of the city manager's tentative decision shall serve as the city manager's final action. 
(d)  An appeal must be requested in writing and must be filed with the city clerk within ten business days of the date of the written notice of the city manager's final action. An appeal shall be scheduled for a hearing before the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting, provided that such meeting is no less than 15 days from the date the written request for an appeal is filed with the city clerk. All appeal hearings are governed by and subject to the provisions of section 12-120. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-122. - Transfers. 
Licenses issued for operation of a business establishment subject to this article are not transferable. Any person or business entity acquiring ownership or control otherwise of an already existing and operating business establishment may not operate the business without first complying with all of the requirements of this article as if a new licensee and receiving a license from the city except that if the business establishment was not required by law to have a special use permit, no special use permit shall be required of the new licensee unless the new licensee intends to relocate the business operation to a new location in the city. If at any time the business establishment licensed by the city ceases operation, the provisions of subsection 12-118(8) may preclude re-establishing the business operation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-123. - To be obtained within two weeks of approval of application. 
(a)  All licenses must be retrieved in person at city hall at which time all regulatory fees shall be paid. No license shall be effective until all regulatory fees have been paid. If retrieval and payment of the regulatory fees is not accomplished within two weeks from the date of the approval of the application, the application and any license otherwise to be issued in response to the application shall be deemed abandoned and void. 
(b)  When a license has been approved and the applicant has deposited with the city clerk's office the required fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, the license shall be issued by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-124. - Renewal. 
All licenses issued pursuant to this article or any predecessor provisions of a city ordinance shall be renewed annually. Renewal requires compliance with all provisions of this article. All licensees shall apply for the renewal of any existing license and pay the renewal application fee and annual regulatory fee no later than February 1 of each calendar year in which business is conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-125. - Annual fee to be set by city council; refunds. 
(a)  Prior to issuance of any license under this article, payment of an annual regulatory fee shall be required. 
(b)  The annual regulatory fee shall be $250.00. 
(c)  All licenses shall be issued for the calendar year beginning January 1, and the fees prescribed by the city council shall be paid in full by each person prior to issuance of a license. 
(d)  Any license issued under this article shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year for which it is issued. 
(e)  In case of the revocation or surrender of such license before the expiration of such calendar year period the holder of the license shall not be entitled to receive any refund whatsoever. 
(f)  The regulatory fee shall be prorated by 50 percent for any business commenced after June 30 of any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-126. - Authorizes conduct of one place of business. 
Each license under this article shall authorize the conduct of one place of business only, and persons doing business in more than one place within the city shall obtain a separate license, paying a separate fee, for each such place of business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-127. - Change of location. 
(a)  The business authorized by a license may be relocated to another address subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  The licensee shall advise the city clerk in writing of the proposed relocation and the new address at which business is proposed to be transacted; 
(2)  If a special use permit is required for the proposed new location of the business, the special use permit must be obtained prior to any relocation and transaction of business at the new address. If a special use permit is required and not obtained, then the business may not relocate; and 
(3)  Operation of the business at the new location is otherwise compliant with the city's zoning regulations. 
(b)  If relocation is permitted, a new business license for the new business location shall be issued upon payment of a fee in an amount to be set by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-128. - Display. 
All licenses issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business authorized by the license. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-129. - Time limit for commencement of business in licensed establishment; abandonment for non-use. 
(a)  All holders of licenses under this article must, within 30 days after the issuance of the license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment within the 30-day period shall constitute abandonment of the license, voiding the license, and rendering unlawful any effort to transact business pursuant to such license. 
(b)  Any holder of a license under this article who commences operation of the business as authorized in the license, but who shall for a period of 30 days thereafter cease to operate the business authorized in the license shall be deemed to have abandoned the license, voiding the license, and rendering unlawful any effort to transact business thereafter pursuant to such license. 
(c)  No refund of application or regulatory license fees shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-130. - Constitutes grant or privilege. 
(a)  All licenses issued under this article are a mere grant or privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license, subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article and any other ordinance, resolution or law of the city, county, state or United States relating to such business. 
(b)  All licenses issued under this article shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be revoked or suspended by the city in accordance with such procedures as adopted by the city." 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-131. - Penalties for failure to obtain or failure to gain permission to transfer. 
If any person or entity fails to apply for and obtain a license as required by this article, then, in addition to any other remedy available under this article or other applicable law, the person or entity is liable to the city for a penalty equal to ten percent of the regulatory fee which shall be imposed for each period of 30 days or portion thereof during which the person or entity unlawfully transacts business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-132. - Collection of unpaid fees. 
Upon the failure to pay any regulatory fee as required by this article, any such fee is subject to collection in the manner as provided for the collection of taxes, regardless of the provisions of this article for penalties. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-133. - Void licenses. 
Any license issued in violation of any provision or requirement of this article or any other applicable legal requirement is void. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Secs. 12-134—12-161. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUSINESS OPERATION 

Sec. 12-162. - Employee regulations. 
(a)  Every person who works in a pawnshop is required to have a permit issued by the city. No permit shall be issued unless the person satisfies the requirements in this section or as otherwise required by the article. The permit required by this section expires annually on the date established generally for the business license of the pawnshop, and each person is required to renew their permit by that date. The permit required by this section must be in the possession of the person while performing services at the pawnshop or elsewhere on behalf of the licensee and must be available for inspection. For purposes of this section "person" includes, but is not limited to, employees, the licensee and, if a corporation, its officers, directors, and shareholders and, if a partnership, its partners, as well as the designated responsible person. It is the duty of the licensee to ensure compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  No licensee shall allow any person to work on the premises or undertake work on behalf of the licensee unless the person has in his or her possession a current, valid city permit, and licensees are required to inspect and verify that each such person has in his or her possession a valid, current pawnshop permit. 
(b)  The following must be provided in connection with seeking a permit: 
(1)  A completed and signed application filed with the chief of police or his designee. The application shall, at a minimum, require the applicant's name, residential address, telephone number, email address, social security number, date of birth, and a description of the applicant's prior arrest record that shall only be used for investigative purposes and shall not give rise to a presumption or inference of guilt. The applicant must also provide proof of identify at the time of submitting the application, and only official, government-issued, photo identification is acceptable (e.g., driver's license, passport, military card, or state identification card). The city may from time to time require additional information of applicants; 
(2)  A SAVE affidavit, a secure and verifiable document and immigration documents (if applicable) indicating the applicant is a U.S. citizen or otherwise qualified alien; 
(3)  A signed consent form authorizing the chief of police or his designee to conduct a criminal background check on the applicant. The chief of police or his designee shall conduct a complete and exhaustive search relative to any police record of the applicant; and 
(4)  Payment of an administrative fee in an amount of $25.00. 
(c)  Persons are ineligible for a permit if: 
(1)  They have been convicted of or pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling, any felonies, or any misdemeanor crimes involving theft, deception or fraudulent practices within ten years preceding the date of application. For purposes of this article, a conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere entered under the Georgia First Offender Act, O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq., shall not be considered. Provided, however, that any such offense shall be considered and be deemed disqualifying where the applicant violated any term of probation imposed by the court granting first offender status or committed another crime and the sentencing court entered an adjudication of guilt as to the crime for which the defendant had previously been sentenced as a first offender; 
(2)  They are subject to outstanding criminal warrants, criminal charges, accusations or indictments for any of the crimes enumerated in this section on which there has been no final disposition or adjudication whereupon any application involving such pending charges shall be held for a final decision until final disposition or adjudication of the charges; 
(3)  For purposes of working in or on behalf of a pawnshop that deals in firearms, a person must be eligible under then prevailing state law to possess a firearm, and the person must retain eligibility throughout employment in accordance with state law as it may be amended from time to time; 
(4)  If it is determined that they falsified, concealed, or misrepresented any material fact by any device, trick, or scheme while making application to the City for a permit under this section. No permit shall be deemed effective absent compliance with this provision, and a failure to comply constitutes abandonment of and voids the application and permit sought; 
(5)  They have previously violated any provision of this article; or 
(6)  They are a city employee who is directly involved in the licensing, permitting, and regulation of pawnshops. 
(d)  In the event the applicant satisfies the criteria established in this section and may otherwise be applicable in this article, the chief of police or his designee shall notify the applicant that a permit has been issued. The applicant must make himself or herself available, within one week of notification, to the chief of police or his designee for photographing for the purpose of issuing the permit. 
(e)  If the permit is denied, the chief of police or his designee shall notify the applicant in writing with a description of the reason(s) for the denial and informing the applicant of the right to appeal the denial to the city manager. Any appeal to the city manager must be presented in writing to the city clerk within ten days of the date of the written denial, and the document filed with the city clerk must provide an explanation by the applicant of the reason for the appeal. Within ten days the city manager shall inform the applicant in writing whether the denial is upheld or reversed. The decision of the city manager is final, subject to review in the Superior Court of Paulding County by way of a petition for a writ of certiorari in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1 et seq. 
(f)  Any permit issued in contravention of this section, article, or any other applicable provision of law is void and may be revoked and seized by the chief of police or his designee, subject to appeal rights as provided in subsection 12-162(e) of this article. 
(g)  All permits issued hereunder remain the property of the police department and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of any officer or designee of the city police department. 
(h)  Replacement permits will be issued within 30 days of the original date, upon paying one-half of the fee charged for pawnshop permits. After 30 days of the original application date, a new application and fee must be submitted. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-163. - Reporting requirement for employee information. 
Twice annually, during the month of June and again during the month of December, the licensee must file with the chief of police or his designee, a document identifying the name of the establishment and its address, the occupation tax certificate number, and all persons conducting or transacting business on behalf of the licensee along with each such person's date of birth, Social Security Number, residential address and telephone number, and email address. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-164. - Adding merchandise to stock. 
(a)  A 51 percent majority of pawned or pledged merchandise must be maintained in inventory for sale at all times if a licensee is also selling new merchandise. 
(b)  A licensee must maintain a documented, objective, and verifiable record of the retail value of all new merchandise made available for sale as well as for the pawned or pledged merchandise made available for sale. The city reserves the right to inspect these records for purposes of determining compliance. 
(c)  A licensee is prohibited from operating its business on the same premises as a business that sells, deals in, exchanges, markets, or handles new goods, wares, or merchandise, and a licensee is prohibited from permitting or otherwise allowing any other business operation on the licensee's premises. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-165. - Articles not to be disposed of for 30 days after acquisition. 
Any licensee who takes goods on pawn or buys goods, taking full title thereto, the word "goods" being here used in the broadest sense and including all kinds of personal property, shall hold such goods so taken in pawn or purchased for at least 30 days before disposing of such goods by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. Failure to comply with this section shall constitute an offense, punishable according to section 12-114. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-166. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful to receive in pawn, pledge or sale goods of any character or description from a minor. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-167. - Sale of knives, blackjacks and other weapons. 
It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale or expose for sale any kind of metal knucks, dirks, sword-in-canes, spears, Bowie knives, switchblade knives, or any blackjacks or similar weapons. Violation of this section shall be punished as provided for in section 12-114. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-168. - Records and information to be maintained; display of pawnshop transaction number; identification; digital photographs; fingerprints; records storage. 
(a)  In the public interest and as set forth herein, licensees shall maintain records documenting all pawnshop transactions. The records shall provide accurate descriptions of all property pledged, traded, pawned, exchanged, or sold to the pawnbroker. Such descriptions shall include, to the extent possible, the manufacturer, model, serial number, style, material, kind, color, design, number of stones if jewelry, and all other identifying names, marks, and numbers. The licensee shall assign a pawnshop transaction number documenting each transaction, and ensure each item received is tagged with the pawnshop transaction number. 
(b)  The tag bearing the pawnshop transaction number must remain attached to the item until the property is disposed of by sale, trade, or other lawful means. This subsection does not apply to the purchase of property from licensed wholesale or distributor businesses for the purpose of retail sales; however the licensee shall be required to maintain all purchasing records for property exempted from this subsection. 
(c)  The licensee shall require all persons pledging, trading, pawning, exchanging, or selling property to show proper identification prior to conducting a transaction. Proper identification is defined as a government issued photo identification card such as a driver's license, military identification card, state identification card, or passport. 
(d)  The licensee shall also document the name, address, telephone number, race, sex, height, weight, driver's license number, date of birth, and social security number of the person pledging, trading, pawning, exchanging, or selling the property, along with the date and time of transaction, including the amount loaned/paid and any check number written for payment. This documentation shall be made at the time of the transaction. 
(e)  There shall be no erasures or blanks on any of the documentation required by this section. Corrections shall be marked through with a solid line and signed by the employee or other person acting on behalf of the licensee making the correction. 
(f)  The licensee is required to photograph the person pledging, trading, pawning, exchanging, or selling the property. The photograph shall be taken with a digital camera at the time of the transaction. The photograph shall clearly show a frontal view of the subject's face along with the pawnshop transaction number. The digital photograph shall be labeled and stored in such a manner that it is safe from corruption, readily identifiable, and readily available for review. 
(g)  The licensee shall obtain from each person pledging, trading, pawning, exchanging, or selling any property, the fingerprint of the right hand index finger, unless such finger is missing, in which event the print of the next finger in existence on the right hand shall be obtained with a notation as to the exact fingerprinted. The fingerprint shall be imprinted onto the pawn transaction form in the designated area along with the signature of the person pawning, trading, pledging, exchanging, or selling the property. The fingerprint must be clear and legible. In the event that more than one pawn transaction form is required, a fingerprint and signature should be obtained for each form. Fingerprints and the information required herein shall be obtained each time such person pledges, trades, pawns, exchanges, or sells any property. 
(h)  Items of property that appear to be new, unused, and in their original packaging cannot be accepted unless the customer can supply to the licensee at the time of the transaction a copy of the original sales receipt or other proof of purchase from the place of purchase. In lieu of the original receipt or proof of purchase, a confirmation of ownership form may be accepted at the licensee's risk. The licensee shall retain the receipt, proof of purchase, or confirmation of ownership on file. 
(i)  The licensee shall store the records required in this section, including all digital images and fingerprints, for a period of four years and make them available to law enforcement personnel upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Sec. 12-169. - Daily report to police. 
(a)  Contents of daily report. 
(1)  Every pawnshop shall prepare a daily report in writing for the police department, in such form as may be prescribed by the police department or any designated agent, of all property that has been the subject of a pawn transaction during the 24 hours ending at 8:00 p.m. on the date of the report. Such report shall be computer generated, typewritten or printed legibly. In addition to any other information required by the police department, the report shall show: 
a.  The name and address of the licensee; 
b.  Time of transaction; 
c.  Serial number of pawn tickets; 
d.  Amount paid or advanced; 
e.  Full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry, and all identifying names, marks and numbers; and 
f.  A description of persons pledging, selling or pawning, including name, address, driver's license number, weight and height. 
(2)  Serial numbers on items with serial numbers must be included in this report. Insufficient reports shall be rejected, and any licensee or representative of licensee making such report shall be deemed guilty of an offense punishable according to the provisions of section 1-12. The daily report shall be in such form and contain such information as may be required by the police chief or by his designated agent, and sufficient information to identify each of such articles. Any person subject to this article, any licensee or employee of a licensee, who shall fail or refuse to prepare and keep reports as provided in this section or shall make false entries concerning the transactions named, or who shall fail or refuse to permit an inspection or examination by any police officer of the reports and of the property pledged or sold to licensee shall be punished as provided for in section 1-12. 
(b)  The report shall be signed and dated by the licensee, if an individual, or by the responsible person, if a corporate or other business entity. The licensee, as well as the person signing the daily report, is responsible for ensuring the completeness and accuracy of the report. 
(c)  The failure of any licensee or representative of the licensee to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute an offense punishable as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, § 1(Exh. A), 12-10-2013) 
Secs. 12-170—12-191. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EXCISE TAX ON ROOMS, LODGING, AND ACCOMMODATIONS 

Sec. 12-192. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is declared the purpose and the intent of the city that an excise tax be levied upon any room or rooms, lodgings and accommodations furnished for value within the city and that said funds be made available for the purpose of promoting, attracting, stimulating and developing tourism within the city and for the provision of other city services. 
(b)  The city does hereby levy and impose an excise tax of five percent upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground or any place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.1) 
Sec. 12-193. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be as defined herein: 
City means the City of Hiram, Georgia, and variously, the incorporated territory of the city, wherein the city is empowered to impose this tax by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
City manager means the duly appointed city manager or his designee. 
Due date means from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
Estimated tax liability means the operator's prospective tax liability based upon tax remittance in the prior fiscal year, as adjusted for change in tax rate or substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the hotel. 
Folio means primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the operator and the occupant and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date of occupancy, the amount of rent charged for each date together with the amounts of applicable excise tax and the method of payment. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, truck stop, tourist cabin, campground, lodge, inn, time-share or other condominium, apartment community, public club or private club, containing guestrooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, jail, prison, or other buildings in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
Monthly period means the calendar month of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to use or possession of any guestroom or apartment in a hotel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guestroom in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in the city, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel and who is subject to the taxation imposed for furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guestroom in a hotel for not less than 30 continuous days next preceding such date. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States, the State of Georgia and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Tax means the tax imposed by this article, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.2) 
Sec. 12-194. - Tax rate. 
There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guestroom in any hotel in the city a tax at the rate of five percent of the amount of any rent unless an exemption is provided under section 12-197. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.3) 
Sec. 12-195. - Collection of tax by operator. 
Every operator renting guestrooms in this city shall collect a tax of five percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exemption is provided under section 12-197. The operator shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other taxes applicable. This tax shall be due from the occupant, and shall be collected by the operator at the same time that the rent is collected. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.4) 
Sec. 12-196. - Proceeds of tax; expenditure. 
(a)  Proceeds of the tax. The proceeds of the tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). 
(b)  Expenditure of proceeds. 
(1)  A portion of the taxes collected shall be paid to the county chamber of commerce or any other entity or organization allowable under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-41 and as may be amended in the future pursuant to a contract with same, and expended for the purposes of promoting tourism, conventions, and trade shows in the city. In this regard, the county chamber of commerce must spend such monies on planning, conducting or participating in programs of information and publicity designed to attract or advertise tourism, conventions or trade shows in the city. The portions to be paid to the county chamber of commerce shall be as follows: An amount equal to the amount by which the total taxes collected under this article exceed the taxes which would have been collected at a rate of three percent; 
(2)  Prior to the beginning of each fiscal year, the county chamber of commerce shall provide to the governing authority a budget detailing the proposed expenditure of the funds provided under this article. Such budget, after being approved by the governing authority, shall be made a part of the budget for the city; 
(3)  The county chamber of commerce shall provide to the governing authority audit verification that the county chamber of commerce has made use of the funds in conformity with the proposed budget and the general purpose of this article. The county chamber of commerce shall also complete a department of community affairs hotel/motel tax report and project/contractor information schedule. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.5) 
Sec. 12-197. - Exemption. 
No tax shall be collected from an occupant after becoming a permanent resident; or from an occupant who certifies in writing that he is staying in such accommodations as a result of his residence having been destroyed by fire or other casualty; or from the United States and the state or any instrumentality of either thereof; or from any official of employee of the state, its units of local government or any other instrumentality of the state, when traveling on official business and presenting written substantiation thereof or paying by state or local government credit or debit card; or from a foreign diplomat exempted by treaty or consular convention, when presenting substantiation issued by the United States Department of State. Occupancy provided without charge in money or otherwise is exempt from this tax. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.6) 
Sec. 12-198. - Registration of operator; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging in or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in this city shall immediately register with the city clerk, on a form provided by said official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than 30 days after the date that this article becomes effective. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place of business and such other information which would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by the city manager. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.7) 
Sec. 12-199. - Determination generally; returns, payments. 
(a)  Due dates of taxes. All amounts of such tax shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. The tax shall become delinquent for each monthly period after the 20th day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax by due date. An operator who fails to make any return or to pay the amount of tax as prescribed, shall be assessed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for one month or less; and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00, whichever is greater. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. 
(c)  Acceptance of delinquent return and remittance without imposing penalty and interest; authority; requirements. If the failure to make any return or to pay the amount of tax by the due date results from providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the governing authority of the city by affidavit attached to the return, and remittance is made within ten days of the due date, such may be accepted exclusive of penalty and interest. 
(d)  Waiving of penalty and interest; authority. O.C.G.A. § 48-2-41, relating to the authority to waive interest, and O.C.G.A. § 48-2-43, relating to the authority to waive penalty, shall apply; provided, however, that the governing authority shall stand in lieu of the state commissioner of revenue, and the city shall stand in lieu of the state. 
(e)  Penalty for fraud. In the case of a false or fraudulent return, or of failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due, a penalty of 50 percent shall be assessed. 
(f)  Return; remittance; time of filing; operators required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month succeeding each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period together with appropriate remittance shall be filed with the city manager. The return shall report the gross rent, taxable rent, exempt rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city manager. However, if the estimated tax liability for any monthly period shall exceed $2,500.00 in any three consecutive months, such operator shall file an estimated return and remit not less the 50 percent of the estimated tax liability for the monthly period by the 20th day of that same monthly period. The amount of tax so remitted shall be credited against the amount to be due with the regular return for the monthly period to be filed on the 20th day of the succeeding month. 
(g)  Extension of time of filing; authority; remittance; penalty and interest. The governing authority of the city may, for good cause, extend the time for making returns for not longer than 30 days. No extension shall be valid unless granted in writing upon written application of the operator. Such grant may not be applicable for longer period than 12 consecutive months. An operator granted an extension shall remit tax equaling not less than 100 percent of the tax paid for the corresponding period of the prior fiscal year; such remittance to be made on or before the date the tax would otherwise come due without the grant of extension. No penalty or interest shall be charged during the first ten days of the extension period. 
(h)  Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be three percent of the amount due, but only if the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.8) 
Sec. 12-200. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city manager or his designee is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any operator, the city manager or his designee may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination as provided by this Code and under state law. 
(c)  Notice of determination; service of. The city manager or his designee shall give to the operator written notice of the manager's determination. The notice served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by addressee. 
(d)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in cases of failure to make a return or of fraud, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.9) 
Sec. 12-201. - Determination if no return made; unsatisfactory return. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any operator fails to make a return, the city manager or his designee shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the operator, or as the case may be, of the amount of total rentals in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the operator failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city manager. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in this Code and under state law. 
(b)  Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax. Penalty and interest shall be assessed upon the amount of any determination, as provided by this Code and under state law. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.10) 
Sec. 12-202. - Collection of tax by city. 
(a)  Action for delinquent tax; time for. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city manager or his designee may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalty, interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fee and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Operator selling or quitting business. If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits his business, he shall make a final return and remittance within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(c)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficiently from the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces from the city manager or his designee either a receipt reflecting full payment or a certificate stating no amount is due. 
(d)  Liability for failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. 
(e)  Credit for tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city, it may be offset by the governing authority. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the city manager or his designee, such person shall have three years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the governing authority, the excess amount paid to the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.11) 
Sec. 12-203. - Administration of article; record keeping. 
(a)  Authority of city manager. The city manager or his designee shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax. 
(b)  Records required from operators, etc; form. Every operator renting guestrooms in the city shall preserve, for a minimum of three years, all folios, receipts, certificates of exemption and such other documents as the city manager or his designee may prescribe, and in such form as the clerk may require. Said records shall at times be available for examination within the city. 
(c)  Application for sales tax audit reports. Each year, in the month of January, the city manager or his designee shall request in writing from the state commissioner of revenue any reports of sales tax audits conducted of hotels in the city during the preceding calendar year. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The city manager or his designee or any person authorized in writing by the manager may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guestrooms and any operator liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the city manager or his designee may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in their possession or custody information relating to the rental of guestrooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city manager when required by said official, and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date of occupancy, the basis for exemption, or such other information as the city manager may prescribe. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.12) 
Sec. 12-204. - Violations. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $300.00, or confinement for a term not to exceed three months. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this article is committed, continued or permitted by such person, and shall be punished accordingly. Any operator who fails to register as required herein, or to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city manager, or who renders a false or fraudulent return, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as aforesaid. 
(Ord. of 2-4-2008, § 18-114.13) 
Secs. 12-205—12-231. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - POOLROOMS OR BILLIARD ROOMS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Local governments power to license, regulate, and tax billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2. 

Sec. 12-232. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverage, beer and malt beverage, fortified wine, wine and distilled spirits or spirituous liquor as defined in section 6-1 of chapter 6, pertaining to alcoholic beverages, which definitions are incorporated in this article by reference. 
Billiard room means any public place where a person is permitted to play the game of billiards and for which a charge is made or any form of consideration is required or tendered for use of equipment. (O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1) 
Billiards or pool means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue and includes all forms of the game known as "carom billiards," "pocket billiards," and "English billiards." (O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1) 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-1, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-233. - Sanitation requirements. 
All public billiard rooms shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition and shall comply with all sanitary rules and regulations of the state, the county, and the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-2, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-234. - Use of obstructions and enclosures. 
No person who operates a billiard room in the city shall permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other obstructions forming rooms, stalls or other enclosures. However, this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes or the maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-3, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-235. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard room within the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. or to permit any person to remain in such billiard room between such prohibited hours except regular employees performing necessary labor on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-4, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-236. - Admission of persons under 18 years of age to billiard rooms in which alcoholic beverages are sold. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to play billiards in, or for any other purpose to enter or remain in, a billiard room in which beer, wine, malt beverage, distilled spirits, spirituous liquor, fortified wine, or alcoholic beverages are offered for sale. This subsection shall not apply to persons under 18 years of age who are accompanied by a parent or guardian. However, no minor shall be allowed in billiard rooms between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. 
(b)  In the event that the proprietor of a billiard room is of the opinion that any person desiring admission thereto is under the age of 18 years, he shall require such person to certify his age by producing a legal permit/identification. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-5, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-237. - Posting of placard as to admission of minors. 
Every licensee under this chapter shall post in the room where billiard tables are operated a placard with the language of section 12-236 conspicuously written thereon for the information of the patrons. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-6, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-238. - Gambling; posting of sporting results; sale or use of intoxicating liquors/alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No dice, cards, dominoes, or other games of chance shall be permitted, nor any form of gambling allowed, in any billiard room or in any other business place operated in connection therewith; and such games as Kelly pool, keno, pigeon pool, Parker pool, star pool, scrub, and similar gambling devices are prohibited. No racing or other betting pool shall be exhibited or sold in such place of business. The use of baseball tickers and the posting results of sporting events are expressly prohibited in billiard rooms or in any place operated in connection therewith. 
(b)  Billiard room operators that are licensed to serve malt beverages, beer, wine, fortified wine, distilled spirits, spirituous liquor, and/or alcoholic beverages shall be subject to all ordinances and restrictions of the state, the city, and/or the county. 
(c)  No alcoholic beverages, malt beverage, beer, wine, fortified wine, distilled spirits, and/or spirituous liquor shall be sold, served, or allowed to be used in or on the premises of billiard rooms or any place operated in connection therewith, unless such premises or establishment is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages, malt beverage, beer, wine, fortified wine, distilled spirits and/or spirituous liquor. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-7, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-239. - Applicability of article to billiard tables and billiard room operated by religious orders, charitable institutions and clubs. 
This article shall not apply to billiard tables or billiard rooms operated by private industrial concerns or associations, religious orders, charitable institutions, state, county, or city institutions, fraternal orders, or bona fide clubs using such tables for members or employees only. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-8, 7-3-2012) 
Sec. 12-240. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who has not reached the age of 18 who remains in a billiard room in the city or within prohibited hours or without being accompanied by a parent or guardian in accordance with section 12-236, who makes a false certificate as to age shall be in violation of this article. 
(b)  Any licensee, person, firm or corporation who shall knowingly violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense. Each violation thereof shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. All violations shall be heard and adjudicated in the municipal court of the city and any final decision of the municipal court of the city may be appealed in writing to the superior court of the county by certiorari within 30 days from the date of any final decision. 
(Ord. No. 2012-3, § 12-9, 7-3-2012) 
Secs. 12-241—12-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RELIGIOUS AND CHARITABLE SOLICITING 

Sec. 12-271. - Permit required. 
Any nonprofit person, firm, association, corporation or organization desiring to solicit or canvass upon public areas or to call from house to house in the city for the purpose of raising funds or seeking donations for any religious, charitable or eleemosynary organization shall register with, and obtain a written permit from the chief of police. 
Sec. 12-272. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Any nonprofit person, firm, association, corporation or organization desiring a permit to solicit or canvass upon public areas or to call from house to house in the city shall file, on a form to be supplied by the chief of police, an application stating the following: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Permanent residence address; 
(3)  Name, address and telephone number of employer, firm, corporation or organization represented; 
(4)  Names and address of all persons assisting in the solicitation, canvassing or calling from house to house in the city; and 
(5)  Nature of any merchandise, wares, goods or any similar items to be sold or offered for sale or given away in conjunction with the solicitation, canvassing or calling from house to house in the city. 
(b)  Proof of tax-exempt status shall be required when registering with the chief of police. 
Sec. 12-273. - Nonprofit organization defined. 
No organization shall be considered a nonprofit organization within the meaning of this article except a tax-exempt organization within the meaning of the Internal Revenue Code or the Georgia Income Tax Law as such code and such law are now or hereafter amended. 
Sec. 12-274. - Use of streets. 
(a)  Solicitation, canvassing and collecting is expressly prohibited in public streets, or from occupants of vehicles on public rights-of-way. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person issued a permit under the provisions of this article to conduct any business transaction in any area which is within 35 feet of any street, alley, road or highway. 
Sec. 12-275. - Issuance of permit; identity card. 
Upon proper registration with and payment of such administrative fee as fixed from time to time by the governing authority to the chief of police, a written permit shall be issued to be valid for a period of 14 days from the date of issuance. A permit shall not be issued more frequently than every three months. In addition, an identifying letter shall be issued by the city and a photograph made which must be carried by all persons while engaged in solicitation, or canvassing upon public areas or calling from house to house in the city. 
Sec. 12-276. - Regulations governing activities. 
Solicitation or canvassing upon public areas or calling from house to house in the city shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  All solicitation, calling or canvassing from house to house in the city shall only occur between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time or 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time. 
(2)  The number of solicitors or canvassers or callers from house to house in the city for any single firm, corporation or organization shall not exceed five in number at any one time. 
(3)  Immediately prior to any solicitation of funds within the city, each solicitor, canvasser or caller shall present his or her identity card, issued by the chief of police, to each person solicited and request each person solicited to read such identity card. Each solicitor or canvasser must inform each person solicited, in clear language, of the nature and purpose of the solicitation, and name and home or national office headquarters of the firm, corporation or organization represented. Each solicitor, canvasser or caller must inform each person solicited as to any minimum donation required for the acceptance of any merchandise, wares, goods or any similar items given by each solicitor, canvasser or called prior to such acceptance by each person solicited. 
Sec. 12-277. - Prohibited acts. 
It shall be unlawful for a solicitor, canvasser or caller to do any of the following: 
(1)  To falsely represent, directly or by implication, that funds being solicited are on behalf of any person, firm, corporation, association or organization other than such registered with the chief of police; 
(2)  To solicit, canvass or call without the express prior permission of any occupant or property owner at any residence, apartment complex, or shopping mall where there is posted a sign forbidding such activity; 
(3)  To remain on private premises after being asked to leave the premises; or 
(4)  To continue solicitation after being refused upon public areas; such action shall constitute harassment. 
Sec. 12-278. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation or organization violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
Secs. 12-279—12-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - COMMERCIAL SOLICITING[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Disabled veteran and blind peddlers exempt from occupation taxes and administrative fees, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1; persons selling agricultural products exempted form from permit requirements, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6. 

Sec. 12-301. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for a peddler, canvasser, solicitor, transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined below to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 12-302. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Canvasser or solicitor means any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not, provided that such definition shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, firm or corporation, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop, or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
Peddler includes any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance, and further provided that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this article. The term "peddler" shall include the terms "hawker" and "huckster." 
Transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engaged in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within said city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, or boat, public room in hotels, lodginghouses, apartments, shops, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction provided that such definition shall not be construed to include any person, firm or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person, firm, or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
Sec. 12-303. - Application. 
Applicants for permits under this article must file with the chief of police a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Address; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification; 
(7)  If a fixed location is o be used, the address and specific location within such address; and 
(8)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance involving theft, deception or injury to persons, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
Sec. 12-304. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application, the chief of police shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the chief of police may appeal such decision to the city manager. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall, upon receipt of payment of the prescribed permit fee, deliver to the applicant his permit. The chief shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
(d)  Upon proper registration with the city, a written permit shall be issued which will be valid for a period of 14 days from the date of issuance. Additionally, a permit shall not be issued more frequently than every six months. 
Sec. 12-305. - Fees; bond; insurance. 
(a)  The permit fee which shall be charged by the city for such permit shall be as fixed from time to time by the governing authority, provided that no fee shall be charged to farmers engaged in direct sales of produce or other farm products produced on their own farms.
