(1)  There is an existence or occupancy of dwellings or other buildings or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business occupancy or use and not in compliance with the applicable state minimum standard codes as adopted by ordinance or operation of law or any optional building, fire, life safety, or other codes relative to the safe use of real property and real property improvements adopted by ordinance in the jurisdiction where property is located within the city limits of the city; or general nuisance law and which constitute a hazard to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of this state, including, but not limited to the residents of the city; and that a public necessity exists for the repair, closing, or demolition of such dwellings, buildings, or structures; 
(2)  It is found and declared that within the city there is in existence a condition or use of real estate which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation; 
(3)  It is found that there exists within the city, dwellings, buildings, or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business uses due to dilapidation and not in compliance with applicable codes; which have defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; which lack adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; or where other conditions exist rendering such dwellings, buildings, or structures unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city, or vacant dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes are being committed, power is conferred upon the city to exercise its police power to repair, close, or demolish the aforesaid dwellings, buildings, or structures in the manner hereinafter provided in this article. 
(Code 1996, § 27-0; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-22. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicable codes means: 
(1)  Any optional housing or abatement standard provided in chapter 2 of title 8 of the O.C.G.A. (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.) as adopted by ordinance or operation of law, or general nuisance law, relative to the safe use of real property; 
(2)  Any fire or life safety code as provided for in chapter 2 of title 25 of the O.C.G.A. (O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq.); and 
(3)  Any building codes adopted by local ordinance prior to October 1, 1991, or the minimum standard codes provided in O.C.G.A. chapter 2 of title 8 (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.) after October 1, 1991, provided that such building or minimum standard codes for real property improvements shall be deemed to mean those building or minimum standard codes in existence at the time such real property improvements were constructed unless otherwise provided by law. 
Closing means causing a dwelling, building or structure to be vacated and secured against unauthorized entry. 
Drug crime means an act which is a violation of O.C.G.A. article 2 of chapter 13 of title 16, known as the Georgia Controlled Substances Act. 
Dwellings, buildings or structures. 
(1)  The term "dwellings," "buildings," or "structures" means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses, improvements, and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. 
(2)  The term "dwellings," "buildings," or "structures" does not mean or include any farm, any building or structure located on a farm, or any agricultural facility or other building or structure used for the production, growing, raising, harvesting, storage, or processing of crops, livestock, poultry, or other farm products. 
Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. 
Parties in interest and/or interested parties mean persons: 
(1)  In possession of said property and premises; 
(2)  Those parties having an interest in the property as revealed by a certification of title to the property conducted in accordance with the title standards of the State Bar of Georgia; 
(3)  Having paid an occupational tax to the city for a location or office at the subject building or structure; 
(4)  Having filed a property tax return with the county as to the subject property, building, or structure; 
(5)  Owner; or 
(6)  Any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records of the petitioner or records maintained in the county courthouse or by the clerk of the superior court of the county. Interested parties shall not include the holder of the benefit or burden of any easement or right-of-way whose interest is properly recorded which interest shall remain unaffected. 
Public authority means any member of governing authority, any housing authority officer, or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the municipality, county, or state relating to health, fire, or building regulations or to other activities concerning dwellings, buildings, or structures in the county or municipality. 
Public officer means the officer who is authorized by O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17 and by this article adopted under O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17 to exercise the powers prescribed by this article or any agent of such officer. 
Repair means altering or improving a dwelling, building or structure so as to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes in the jurisdiction where the property is located and the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, and other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building or structure. 
Resident means any person residing in the jurisdiction where the property is located on or after the date on which the alleged nuisance arose. 
(Code 1996, § 27-1; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-23. - Continued use of other laws and ordinances. 
It is the intent of the governing authority that nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of any local enabling act, charter, ordinance or regulation nor to prevent or punish violations thereof and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance, legislation or regulation. 
(Code 1996, § 27-2; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-24. - Duties of owners; appointment of public officer: procedures for determining premises to be unsafe or unhealthy. 
(a)  It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the jurisdiction to construct and maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with applicable codes in force within the city, or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure or property in violation of such codes or ordinances. 
(b)  The governing authority appoints or designates the police chief or his designee as the public officer to exercise the powers prescribed by this chapter. The governing authority reserves the right to change the appointment or designation of the public officer and/or to designate, and/or appoint others as the public officer to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. 
(c)  Whenever a request is filed with the public officer by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any dwelling, building or structure is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure or property. 
(d)  If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure or property: 
(1)  Is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; 
(2)  Is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or 
(3)  Constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions; 
the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the owner and parties in interest in such dwelling, building or structure. 
(e)  The complaint shall: 
(1)  Identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; 
(2)  Identify the owner and parties in interest; 
(3)  State with particularity the factual basis for the action; and 
(4)  Contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. 
(f)  The summons shall notify the owner and parties in interest that a hearing will be held before a court of competent jurisdiction as determined by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5, at a date and time certain and at a place within the city where the property is located. Such hearing shall be held not less that 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in court. The owner and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. 
(g)  If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that the dwelling, building or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support such determination that a nuisance exists and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and any parties in interest that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: 
(1)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or 
(2)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building or structure in order to bring it into lull compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building or structure and all debris from the property. 
For purposes of this article, the court shall make its determination of reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building or structure without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that costs of the preparation necessary to repair alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be factor in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a state appraiser classification, as provided in O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 39A qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations in force in the jurisdiction. 
(h)  If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building or structure, to be repaired, altered, improved, vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the 270 days in which such abatement action must commence. The public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: 
"This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." 
(i)  If the public officer has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The public officer and the city are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. 
(j)  The amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. 
(1)  The lien provided for in this article shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(c). The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. Upon final determination of costs, fees, and expenses incurred in accordance with this article, the public officer responsible for enforcement actions in accordance with this article shall transmit to the appropriate county tax commissioner or city revenue officer a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the public officer shall be transmitted within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition or closure. It shall be the duty of the county tax commissioner or the city revenue officer, who is responsible to collect the amount of the lien in conjunction with the collection of ad valorem taxes on the property and to collect the amount of the lien as if it were a real property ad valorem tax, using all methods available for collection of real property ad valorem tax, including specifically chapter 4 of title 48 of the O.C.G.A. (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1 et seq.); provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The tax commissioner shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority. 
(2)  Enforcement of liens pursuant to this article may be initiated at any time following receipt by the county tax commissioner or city revenue officer of the final determination of costs in accordance with this article. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this article. 
(3)  The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this article shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this ordinance together with interest, penalties, and costs incurred by the governing authority, county tax commissioner, or city revenue officer in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. 
(4)  The city may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the county or municipality agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property of the dwelling, building or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. 
(5)  Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court of the county under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. 
(6)  The public officer/officers designated herein may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and may seek to enforce such citation in court of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this article. 
(7)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(8)  The failure to abate or remove such nuisance as required by this article shall allow the judge of the municipal court to enforce such failure as an offense and/or as a violation of the city ordinances and issue such fines or other enforcement as allowed by the city Charter for the enforcement of violations of city ordinances and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1996, § 27-3; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-25. - Determination by public officer under existing ordinances that dwellings, buildings or structures are vacant: conditions of nuisances 
(a)  The public officer may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use, if he finds that conditions exist in such building, dwelling, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of: 
(1)  The occupants of such dwelling, building or structure; 
(2)  The occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings or structures; or 
(3)  Other residents of the city. 
(b)  Such conditions include the following, without limiting the generality of the foregoing: 
(1)  Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; 
(2)  Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; 
(3)  Dilapidation; 
(4)  Disrepair; 
(5)  Structural defects; 
(6)  Uncleanliness; and 
(7)  Other additional standards which may from time to time be adopted and referenced herein by ordinance amendment. 
(c)  The public officer may determine under existing ordinances, that a dwelling or building is vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, based upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence that drug crimes are being committed. 
(Code 1996, § 27-4; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-26. - Powers of public officers. 
The public officers designated in this article shall have the following powers: 
(1)  To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial or business use or are vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; 
(2)  To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; 
(3)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents and employees, as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article; and 
(5)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
(Code 1996, § 27-5; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-27. - Service of complaints. 
Complaints issued by a public officer pursuant to this article shall be served in the manner set forth in this section. In all cases, a copy of the complaint and summons shall be conspicuously posted on the subject dwelling, building or structure within three business days of filing of the complaint and at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. A copy of the complaint and summons shall be served in one of the following manner: 
(1)  a.  At least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing, the public officer shall mail copies of the complaint by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identities and addresses are reasonably ascertainable. 
b.  Copies of the complaint shall also be mailed by first class mail to the property address to the attention of the occupants of the property, if any, and shall be posted on the property within three business days of filing the complaint and at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(2)  For interested parties whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriffs advertisements appear in such county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. 
(3)  A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county in which the dwelling, building, or structure is located at the time of filing the complaint in the appropriate court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(4)  Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this section on any interested party who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any interested party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. 
(Code 1996, § 27-5; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-28. - Appeal. 
Any persons or other entity found to be in violation of this article by order of the judge of the municipal court shall have the right to appeal of any such order within 30 days of entry, in writing to the superior court of the county. 
(Code 1996, § 27-7; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Secs. 22-29—22-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE CONTROL 

Sec. 22-85. - General prohibition. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which unreasonably annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the city, and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 50 feet from the point of origin of this sound or noise. 
Sec. 22-86. - Specific acts or conditions deemed loud, disturbing. 
The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary sounds or noises in violation of this article, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place in the city, except as a danger warning; the creation of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of this signaling device and the sounding of this device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust and the use of this signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up is prohibited. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, similar devices. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to unreasonably disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is reasonably necessary for convenient hearing for the person who is in the room, vehicle or chamber in which this machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto. The operation of the set, instrument, phonograph machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the room, building, structure or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this subsection. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure is prohibited. Announcements over loudspeakers shall only be made by the announcer in person and without the aid of any mechanical device. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place so as to unreasonably annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence or of any persons in the vicinity, is prohibited. 
(5)  Noisy animals or birds. Keeping or maintaining an animal or bird that unreasonably disturbs the comfort or repose of any person because the animal or bird is emitting frequent or long-continued sound or noise. This subsection shall not apply to horses, livestock, poultry or other farm animals, provided they are maintained in accordance with the city zoning ordinances. 
(6)  Construction or repair of buildings. The creation of any noise in violation of this chapter due to the erection, excavating, demolition, alteration or repair of any building requiring the issuance of a building permit, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on weekdays and 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Saturdays, is hereby prohibited; except as allowed by the city by permit specifically permitting overnight construction. 
(7)  Transportation of metal rails, similar materials. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material over and along streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any manner so loaded as to cause unreasonably loud noises or as to unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of those streets or other public places is prohibited. 
(8)  Pile drivers, hammers, similar equipment. The operation between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by unreasonably loud or unusual sounds or noises, is prohibited. 
(9)  Blowers and motors. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noises due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids is prohibited; unless the noise from this blower or fan is muffled and the engine is equipped with a muffler device reasonably sufficient to deaden the noise. 
(10)  Steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler is prohibited; except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or a warning of fire or danger upon request of proper authorities. 
(11)  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle, or motor boat is prohibited; except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(12)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create unreasonably loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises is prohibited. 
(13)  Loading, unloading, opening boxes. The creation of unreasonably loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers is prohibited. 
(14)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any unreasonably excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the normal operation of the institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospitals is prohibited; provided, that conspicuous signs are displayed in the streets indicating that it is a school, hospital or court street. 
(15)  Hawkers, peddlers, vendors. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood is prohibited. 
Sec. 22-87. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to or be enforced against: 
(1)  Any vehicle of the city while engaged in necessary public business. 
(2)  Excavations or repairs of streets by or on behalf of the county, city or state at night when public welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform this work during the day. 
(3)  The reasonable use of amplifiers or loudspeakers in the course of public addresses and/or permitted public gatherings. 
(4)  Outdoor entertainment provided at restaurants with outdoor dining areas on private property which are located as shown on the official zoning map/downtown development district provided the outdoor entertainment occurs within the outdoor dining area between the hours of 12:00 noon and 12:00 midnight on Saturdays, and 12:00 noon and 8:00 p.m. on Sundays, and the sound from same does not exceed a sound level plainly audible at a distance more than 100 feet from the point of origin of said sound. 
Secs. 22-88—22-117. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CARE OF PREMISES 

Sec. 22-118. - Findings. 
There is an existence of junk cars, junk motor vehicles and other conditions of property within the city, which are creating a hazard to the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city. There exist a public necessity for removing, repairing, or disposing by demolition or otherwise of such junk cars, junk motor vehicles and other conditions detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1996, § 28-0; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-119. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessory building means a carport, attached or detached garage, storage building or any other not-for-habitation buildings on the premises (as generally defined by statutory and judicial principles in Georgia). 
Derelict automotive vehicle means a vehicle that for a period of at least ten consecutive days: 
(1)  Is physically incapable of traveling under its own power; 
(2)  Is physically capable of traveling under its own power, but during such traveling on a public road would be in violation of any provision of Title 40, Chapter 8, Article I, of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; or 
(3)  Possesses at least one of the following characteristics: 
a.  At least one broken window. 
b.  At least one door that cannot be opened. 
c.  At least one door that cannot be closed. 
d.  Parts of the vehicle are attached to the vehicle with tape or wire. 
e.  Excessive rusting covering at least 30 percent of the body of the vehicle. 
f.  Missing a door, the hood, the trunk cover, or a tire. 
Derelict boat or trailer-type vehicle means a boat or trailer-type vehicle which: 
(1)  Is dismantled, partially dismantled, deteriorated or not safe for use due to disrepair or damage; and 
(2)  Which constitutes a nuisance or health or safety hazard in that it provides a place for insects, rodents, and other animals to exist, attracts children, vagrants, or other individuals and may cause injury to them. 
Established driveway means an area that is paved, graveled, bare of vegetation, or otherwise clearly indicative of the area that is normally used for vehicles to enter onto or exit from real property from or to a public or private street. 
Front yard means that portion of the property running the width of the principal building on the lot as extended to the right-of-way line of an abutting street. If there is no building on the property, the entire property shall be deemed the "front yard." 
Object means any items of personal property, other than a vehicle, boat or trailer-type vehicle, which is not related to the use and purpose for which the real property is occupied or owned or permitted by the applicable zoning classification. The term "objects" under this article shall also include junk materials (any item that has no significant value in its present form); machinery and equipment; appliances or other household items; lumber and building materials; dirt, sand, fill, rock, stone, or other materials not forming part of a structure or landscaping. This definition shall also apply to abandoned tires, dilapidated buildings, and other unsightly accumulations of debris that may be placed on residential, commercial, or industrial property. 
Person means any natural person, corporation, partnership, authority created by statute, association or other entity or combination thereof. 
To place means to establish the presence on property of an object which: 
(1)  Is capable of being moved or removed which is not affixed to the real property; and 
(2)  Is present for a period of ten consecutive days whether or not the location of the item on the property is changed. 
Vehicle, automotive, means an automobile, truck, van, or other motor vehicle designed and intended for use in transporting people and goods. 
(Code 1996, § 28-1; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-120. - Occupants or owners to keep premises free of litter, debris, junk materials, derelict vehicles and overgrowth. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the occupant of premises or the owner of premises to have or to place any of the following on said premises to the extent and in a manner that could threaten or endanger the public health, safety or welfare or could adversely affect and impair the economic value of adjacent property: 
(1)  Any accumulation of litter, debris, refuse, garbage or animal excrement on any front, side, or rear yard or on any porch, or underneath any building or in any accessory building. 
(2)  Any object or objects as defined, on the front yard or on a front porch of residential, commercial, or industrial property. 
(3)  Any object or objects, as defined, on the side or rear yards, or on side or rear porches or underneath any building or in any accessory building unless such objects are completely enclosed within a building or are enclosed with a solid fence of such height that the objects are completely screened from the view of persons on adjacent property and to passers-by on public rights-of-way. 
(4)  Any overgrown grass or weeds of a height of six inches or more or any other unkempt vegetation, including but not limited to dead tree limbs or dead trees, in any yard, front, side or rear. 
(5)  Any storage building on the front yard or any dilapidated storage building on the side or rear yard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat or derelict trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on an established driveway of a front yard, and it shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle, derelict boat or derelict trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on the side or rear yards if visible from a street, lane, or adjoining property unless completely enclosed within an accessory building so as not to be visible from the street, lane, or adjoining property. In the case of a dispute as to the condition of a vehicle, the owner will cooperate with the police chief or his designee to verify the state of repair of the vehicle within five days of notice. If the vehicle owner does not cooperate with the police chief or his designee, the vehicle shall be presumed to be in violation of this article. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to material which is being used in connection with a construction actively taking place on said premises provided the construction activity is being diligently pursued and complies with applicable ordinances and codes. 
(d)  No person shall store, keep, maintain, or allow to be kept for sale on any property which is, zoned for commercial or industrial uses within the city any used, wrecked, dismantled or junk automobiles or vehicles, or any new or used appliances, antiques, furniture, lumber, machinery, equipment, building material, cordage, and similar items and material unless the same is housed in a building. However, property displayed for sale during normal business hours may be stored outside for a period not to exceed 12 hours each business day. Seasonal sales products may be displayed outside during the appropriate season, but in no case shall remain stored outside no longer than 30 days. Any person needing a period of time in excess of 30 days for the outside display of seasonal sales products shall make a written application to the governing authority for such approval. 
(Code 1996, § 28-2; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-121. - Exemptions. 
Derelict automotive vehicles and derelict boat or derelict trailer type vehicles which are exempted from the provisions of this article are those which are: 
(1)  Located on the premises of any licensed dealer of any motor vehicle; 
(2)  Located on the premises of any licensed junkyard operated in compliance with state and local laws relating to licensing, regulating and zoning of any such junkyards; 
(3)  Enclosed within a building on private property which is not a hazard to public health, safety or welfare; 
(4)  In operable condition specifically adapted or designed for operation on drag strips or raceways; 
(5)  In the process of being restored to an operable condition provided they are: 
a.  Limited to no more than one in number; 
b.  Located in the rear yard and behind the house of the owner of such vehicles; 
c.  Not visible from any public street, alley, way, road, or adjoining property; 
d.  Must maintain a current county and/or state tag decal; and 
e.  Are enclosed or covered in such a way so as not to be an attractive nuisance to children. 
(Code 1996, § 28-3; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-122. - Maintenance of commercial and industrial properties. 
All owners and occupants of commercial and industrial properties within the city shall keep buildings and other structures on such property in a good state of repair and free from dilapidation. The following constitute an illustrative, but not exclusive, listing of dilapidated conditions, which constitute a violation of this Code: 
(1)  Broken windows or broken glass in doors; 
(2)  Gutters which are bent, missing, or which have pulled loose from their secured installation; 
(3)  Awnings which are torn, bent, or which present a dilapidated appearance due to holes, missing edging, or discoloration; 
(4)  Roofing material, which is missing, broken or which has blown loose; 
(5)  Peeling or blistered paint; 
(6)  Mildewed exterior surfaces; 
(7)  Repairs utilizing mismatched or substandard materials; 
(8)  Wood which is splintered, rotting, or which has lost its structural integrity; 
(9)  Masonry which has missing pieces or severe cracking; 
(10)  Raw untreated wood exposed to the elements; 
(11)  Any condition which would constitute a violation of the Unsafe Building Abatement Code. 
Sec. 22-123. - Closure of businesses. 
(a)  For all structures designed to be used for or occupied by commercial or industrial uses, but which are currently vacant or are scheduled to become vacant, the owner of the property shall secure such structures for the protection of the property against vandalism and for the aesthetic preservation of the neighborhood and shall maintain such security measures until the building is once again occupied. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the building owner shall remove all signage which no longer refers to a commercial or industrial use of the property, shall cover all windows of the structure with plywood which shall be painted in a color complementary to the building, and shall likewise secure all glass doors with a painted plywood covering. 
(c)  The owner of the vacant commercial or industrial property shall be responsible for maintaining the exterior of the building in accordance with all city codes and ordinances, including this Property Maintenance Code, and shall further be responsible for cleaning the exterior of premises to keep the exterior free from litter and other debris. The owner of such property shall promptly remove any litter and debris left upon the exterior of the property. 
(d)  While an owner may require any of the actions required by this section to be performed by a tenant prior to vacating the premises, such delegation will not relieve the owner from full compliance with this section or negate the owner's liability to the city in any manner whatsoever. 
Sec. 22-124. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever it comes to the attention of the governing authority and/or the chief of police or his designee that any nuisance exists as stated in this article within the incorporated area of the city, a notice or citation in writing shall be served by the police department upon the owner and occupant of the real property within the city where the violation exists, and/or upon the owner of the derelict motor vehicle which constitutes such nuisance, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and directing them to remove such within 30 days of this notice. In the event that such owners cannot be located, or in the event that the address of such owners is unknown, then notice shall be made to the last known address of such owners, or in the event that the identity of such owners cannot be ascertained after due investigation, such notice shall be posted in a prominent location on the premises where the offending condition is located, and upon the object or derelict motor vehicle. 
(Code 1996, § 28-4; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-125. - Responsibility for compliance. 
Upon receipt of the notice as provided in section 22-124, it shall be the responsibility of the owner and/or occupant of the property to remove the object, derelict motor vehicle or other violating condition, bringing the property into compliance with this Code. In the event the owner and/or occupant of the property fails to take such action to eliminate the violating condition within the timeframe set out in the notice, then such person shall be cited to appear before the municipal court to answer to the charge of maintaining a nuisance. At least five days' notice of the court appearance shall be given prior to hearing of any nuisance charge. 
(Code 1996, § 28-5; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-126. - Hearing. 
(a)  At the hearing, the judge of municipal court shall determine the owner and/or the person who is in control or possession of the property covered by the notice and whether or not a nuisance as defined by this article exists. If so, the judge of the municipal court shall order an abatement or removal of such nuisance and/or shall impose such penalty or penalties for an offense as may be authorized by this article or any other applicable ordinance for failure to abate or remove such nuisance. 
(b)  In the event that the judge of the municipal court determines by written findings of fact, that a nuisance exists and abatement or removal the thereof is ordered, the judge of the municipal court shall be authorized to grant the owner and/or person who is in control or possession of the premises a period of time, not to exceed 15 days, to abate or remove such nuisance. The judge of the municipal court shall further include in such order provisions authorizing the police department to abate or remove such nuisance if such nuisance is not abated or removed by the owner or person in control or possession of the premises within the time period for such abatement or removal as ordered. Such order shall also include authority for the police department or any authorized city contractor to enter upon the premises or real property upon which the nuisance exists and to abate or remove the same, and shall further provide that the cost incurred by the police department of abatement or removal of the nuisance incurred by the city shall be assessed against the owner or person in control or possession of the premises or real property. 
(Code 1996, § 28-6; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-127. - Abatement by the city. 
In the event that the nuisance is abated or removed by the police department pursuant to order of the judge of the municipal court as authorized herein, the police department shall be authorized to abate or remove the nuisance in the following manner: 
(1)  The police department may acquire a wrecker service, or such other service or assistance or personnel as may be required to remove or abate the nuisance, which shall include, but be limited to, the ability to direct that the nuisance be removed or abated by removal to a local licensed junkyard or other similar storage facility. 
(2)  The police department shall notify the owner of the premises or real property upon which the nuisance exists, and/or the person in control or possession or the owner of said object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer within ten days of any such removal, the location of the object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer and of the cost incurred by the police department in connection with the abatement or removal. Such cost may include the actual cost of removal of the object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer and any storage charges, if applicable. 
(3)  In the event that the owner of the premises or real property upon which a nuisance exists and/or the person in control or possession or the owner of such object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer does not pay all of the costs incurred and/or storage charges as stated in subsection (2) of this section in order to recover or obtain the object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer within 30 days from any such removal as allowed by this article, the governing authority shall be authorized to dispose of such object, derelict motor vehicle or derelict boat or boat trailer in any manner as may be authorized and allowed by the laws of the state and/or the ordinances in order to recover the costs incurred and/or storage charges as allowed by this article. 
(Code 1996, § 28-7; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-128. - Failure to abate. 
The failure to abate or remove such nuisance as required by this article shall allow the judge of the municipal court to enforce such failure as an offense and/or as a violation of the ordinances and issue such fines or other enforcement as allowed by the city Charter for the enforcement of violations of city ordinances and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1996, § 28-8; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Sec. 22-129. - Appeal. 
Any persons or other entity found to be in violation of this article by order of the judge of the municipal court shall have the right to appeal any such order within 30 days of entry, by certiorari, to the superior court of the county. 
(Code 1996, § 28-9; Ord. of 11-15-2011) 
Chapter 24 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court or magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; abandoned motor vehicles generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 24-1. - Camping in public. 
No person shall camp in the streets, sidewalks or public parks of the city without permission from the governing authority. 
Sec. 24-2. - Building fires in public places. 
No person shall build a fire in the streets, sidewalks or city park other than in established barbeque devices without permission from the fire official. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 5; Code 1996, § 46-2) 
Sec. 24-3. - Fastening bills to poles and trees. 
No person shall paste or in any manner fasten any bills, advertisements or any other notices to any telephone, electric or telegraph pole or any shade tree in the city. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 9; Code 1996, § 46-3) 
Sec. 24-4. - Firearms and BB guns. 
No person shall fire a gun, pistol or other firearm, or fire or discharge any airgun, commonly known as a BB gun, in the city. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 10; Code 1996, § 46-4) 
Sec. 24-5. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful and disorderly conduct for any person to: 
(1)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby a reasonable person would be placed in fear of safety for life or limb; 
(2)  Place the property of another in serious danger of being destroyed or damaged; 
(3)  Use fighting words directed toward another, who becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; 
(4)  Violently interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; 
(5)  Congregate with others to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuse to clear the way when ordered by lawful authority to do so; 
(6)  Use any type of profane or lewd language in a public place that is offensive to another, causes another to become outraged and thus creates a turmoil; or 
(7)  Urinate, defecate, or release bodily fluids in any public area. As used in this subsection, the term "public area" means sidewalks, parking lots, streets, parks, trails or any area in which the public would reasonably be expected to frequent or visit. 
State Law reference— Authority to punish disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 24-6. - Public drunkenness. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in an intoxicated condition on any public street or highway or within the curtilage of any private residence not in exclusive possession of the person so intoxicated, or upon any railway passenger train or other public conveyance, or at or on ballgrounds, parks and swimming pools, or at any other place or public gathering or assembly, where such drunkenness is caused by the excessive use of intoxicating beverages or opiates. Such drunkenness must be made manifest by boisterousness or by indecent condition or behavior or by vulgar, profane, or unbecoming language, or loud and violent discourse of the person so intoxicated. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 24; Code 1996, § 46-8) 
State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 24-7. - Resisting an officer. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to oppose or resist any police officer of this city in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 25; Code 1996, § 46-9) 
State Law reference— Hindering apprehension of criminals, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-50; fleeing or attempting to elude police officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-395. 
Sec. 24-8. - Theft or injury of city property. 
No person shall take, mar, deface, soil or in any manner injure, disturb or interfere with any city property. 
(Code 1965, ch. 10, § 29; Code 1996, § 46-13) 
State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with utilities, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 24-9. - Public nudity. 
It shall be unlawful for any person over four years of age within the incorporated area of the city to knowingly or intentionally appear in a state of nudity in any public place including, but not limited to, establishments that accommodate the public. The term "nudity" means the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple, or the showing of the covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. Any person who violates this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1996, § 46-16; Ord. No. 91-40, 9-3-1991) 
Sec. 24-10. - Hours of operation for city parks. 
(a)  The hours of operation for all city parks are from 7:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. Only authorized city employees or persons engaged in activities authorized by the city manager, or the designee thereof, are permitted in any city park outside of hours of operation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except a properly authorized city employee, to be in or on any city park property beyond the established hours of operation without permission from the city manager, or the designee thereof. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to disregard an order from a city police officer or code enforcement officer to leave city park property. 
(d)  Any person who violates this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, 4-3-2018) 
Chapter 26 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Pursuant to the Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq., the city is included in the county's comprehensive solid waste management plan adopted February 7, 1994. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Unauthorized accumulations. 
No person shall keep or store garbage, trash or solid waste outside of any residence or building within the city, except in proper containers for collection or otherwise prepared, as set forth in article II of this chapter or under the express prior approval of the city manager or his designee. No garbage, trash or solid waste improperly contained will be collected by the city garbage collection service. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is further hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. The city manager or his designee, by written notice, shall notify the owner or occupant of any premises with such garbage, trash or solid waste accumulations to remove such accumulations. Failure to remove such accumulations within two weeks of the date of such written notice to do so shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and subject to penalties set forth in the general penalties described in section 1-12. A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues. 
(Code 1996, § 50-1; Ord. of 3-3-1980) 
Secs. 26-2—26-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Garbage collection and disposal is carried out in the city by contract. A copy of such contract is on file in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 26-21. - Containers; specifications; replacement. 
Garbage containers shall be provided by the owner or occupant of each residence or establishment sufficient in number to accommodate such waste generated by the residence or establishment between collections. Containers shall be of durable metal or plastic, watertight, nonabsorbent, rust resistant, rodentproof, and easily cleanable. They shall be equipped with handles and tightly fitted covers and shall have a capacity of not less than 15 gallons nor more than 55 gallons. Containers failing to comply with this section, or which have defects causing them to scatter waste upon the ground during collection, or causing them to hamper or to injure the persons collecting waste shall be promptly replaced. 
(Code 1996, § 50-31; Ord. of 3-3-1980) 
Sec. 26-22. - Collection; monthly charge. 
Garbage, trash and solid waste shall be collected from residential premises weekly at a monthly charge as may be set from time to time by resolution of the governing authority and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(Code 1996, § 50-32; Ord. of 3-3-1980) 
Chapter 26A - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT ORDINANCE 

Sec. 26A-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the protection of the public health, welfare, and safety by prescribing the conditions and requirements for solid waste collection, transportation, disposal, and management and penalties for noncompliance; to protect and preserve the environment through these conditions and requirements and establishment of a recycling program for various residential solid waste; and to accomplish these goals as efficiently and economically as possible. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-2. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the City of Hiram, Georgia "Solid Waste Management Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-3. - Scope of ordinance. 
This chapter applies only to the collection and disposal of residential refuse. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-4. - Definitions. 
Unless the context indicates otherwise, the meaning of certain terms used in this chapter is as follows: 
City means the City of Hiram, Georgia. 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by any commercial establishment including, but not limited to, stores, offices, warehouses, restaurants, and other manufacturing and nonmanufacturing activities. 
Construction/remodeling/demolition waste means waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, and demolition operations to structures or property, including, but not limited to, wood, brick, metal, concrete, wall board, and other similar types of non-putrescible wastes generated by such activities. 
Franchise means the authorization bestowed by the governing authority pursuant to this chapter to be the person provider the solid waste collection, transportation, and disposal services described in this chapter. 
Franchisee means that person selected by the governing authority and authorized by resolution to provide the solid waste collection and disposal services provided for by this chapter. 
Hazardous waste means solid or liquid waste material resulting from the manufacture or use of pesticides and drugs (other than normal household use); pathological wastes; highly flammable or explosive wastes; toxic wastes; sewage sludge; and other waste material determined to be a likely hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare including, but not limited to, asbestos and asbestos containing waste, lead and lead containing waste, radioactive materials, and all other materials classified as hazardous by state and federal law. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Putrescible waste means waste that is capable of being decomposed by microorganisms, including kitchen wastes, manure, and household garbage. 
Refuse means and includes the terms garbage, solid waste, recyclable materials, refuse, rubble, rubbish, trash, and other similar forms of putrescible and non-putrescible waste. 
Residential refuse means solid waste derived from single-family households including refuse, garbage, trash, ashes, paper and paper products, agricultural product, and other similar types of putrescible waste. The term does not include yard waste and trimmings, white goods such as appliances and furniture, any construction/remodeling/demolition waste, or any commercial solid waste. 
When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense and words in the singular also include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory not merely directory. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-5. - Establishment of exclusive franchise for collection and disposal of residential solid waste. 
(a)  Except as provided otherwise in this chapter, no person other than a franchisee duly authorized by the governing authority shall collect, transport, or dispose of residential refuse in the city. 
(b)  Commencing after the first award by resolution of a franchise contract to a franchisee by the governing authority, requests for proposal shall be issued every three years soliciting proposals for the collection, transportation, and disposal of residential refuse. The city shall not be required to accept any proposal so submitted but may reject all proposals and rebid the award of the franchise contract as determined by the governing authority to be in the best interests of the city and the public health, welfare, and safety. 
(c)  The request for proposals shall prescribe the terms, conditions, and requirements for due consideration of a proposal as well as the terms, conditions, and requirements for any franchise contract authorized to the extent not contrary to the language of this chapter or any other provision of law. Those responding to requests for proposal must also comply with all other requirements of law governing the provision of services to the city as they may be established or exist from time to time. 
(d)  By resolution the governing authority shall select a person to provide all residential refuse collection, transportation, and disposal. Such a selection shall be exclusive, meaning that the person provided shall be the sole provider of residential refuse collection, transportation, and disposal throughout the city. 
(e)  No award of a franchise or any services to be provided thereof as provided for in this chapter may be delegated, assigned, or otherwise transferred to any other person without the express permission of the governing authority, to be evidenced only by a duly authorized resolution to that effect. 
(f)  Any person wanting to be considered for award of the exclusive franchise must meet the following minimum requirements and provide proper proof thereof: 
(1)  Application shall be made as prescribed in a request for proposal. Proposals failing to provide the information prescribed in the request for proposal shall not be accepted or considered; 
(2)  A notarized statement certifying that all solid waste collection, transportation, and disposal equipment meets the minimum requirements of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and any State of Georgia counterpart and, as applicable, the minimum requirements of the Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT); 
(3)  A notarized statement certifying that all heavy equipment drivers and operators are properly licensed as required by law; 
(4)  Proof that the proposer, if awarded the franchise, will have the right to use a lawful site to dispose of the residential refuse to be collected and transported along with a letter of solid waste disposal assurance governing the next three years from the owner or operator where the solid waste is to be delivered attesting to the ability to accept and dispose of, within all bounds of applicable law, the solid waster to be delivered for disposal and describing what arrangements are in place to do so; and 
(5)  Proof of general liability insurance and workers' compensation as prescribed in this chapter. 
(g)  The franchise authorized by this chapter shall continue in force for a period of three years from the date of authorization, unless terminated earlier as provided for in this chapter or franchise agreement; provided, however, that within ten days after the passage of this chapter the franchisee initially authorized by the governing authority shall file with the city manager in writing its unconditional acceptance of this franchise and promise to comply with and abide by all its provisions, terms, and conditions of this chapter. 
(h)  The franchisee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city, its elected officials, officers, agents and employees as a result of the grant of this franchise. Such indemnification shall be for, but not limited to, negligence on the part of the franchisee in the maintenance and operation of its refuse collection services. 
(i)  The franchisee shall pay all expenses incurred by the city, its elected officials, officers, agents and employees in defending itself or themselves with regard to all damages and penalties mentioned in subsection (h) above. These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, such as attorney's fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by the city attorney or his assistants or any employees of the city. 
(j)  A certificate showing that insurance coverage has been obtained and is currently in force and effect shall be filed with the city manager prior to the commencement of service by the franchisee and within 30 days of the anniversary date of the policy in each and every year. 
(k)  The franchisee shall maintain insurance with a reputable company or companies licensed to do business in the State of Georgia to protect the city and the franchisee from any and all claims, injury or damage to the persons or property, both real and personal, caused directly or indirectly by the operation of the refuse collection service. The amount of such insurance shall be equivalent to that maintained by the city but, in no event, shall the insurance be less than $300,000.00 for property damage, per occurrence, $500,000.00 for personal injury, per person, and $1,000,000.00 for personal injury per occurrence. Workmen's compensation insurance shall also be maintained as required by the laws of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-6. - Termination of franchise. 
(a)  In addition to all other rights and powers pertaining to the city by virtue of this franchise or otherwise, the city reserves the right to terminate or cancel this franchise and all rights and privileges of the franchisee hereunder in the event that the franchisee: 
(1)  Violates any provision of this franchise or any rule, order, or determination of the city or the governing authority pursuant to this franchise, except where such violation is without fault or through excusable neglect; 
(2)  Revocation of any permit, license, or other permission from any governmental authority necessary to engage in the collection, transportation, and disposal of residential refuse or the failure to timely obtain a renewal of any such permit, license, or other permission; 
(3)  Violation of any law applicable to the collection, transportation, and disposal of residential refuse, including all rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources and any rules of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency; 
(4)  Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged bankrupt; 
(5)  Attempts to evade any of the provisions of this franchise or practices any fraud or deceit upon the city or the customers served; 
(6)  Franchisee has a change in the ownership of 50 percent or more of its stock, without the city's consent; or 
(7)  As otherwise provided for in a franchise agreement provided that no provisions in the franchise agreement may override or conflict with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Such termination and cancellation shall be by resolution duly adopted after 30 days notice to the franchisee and shall in no way affect any of the city's rights under this franchise or any provision of law. In the event that such termination and cancellation depends upon a finding of fact, such findings of fact as made by the governing authority or its designee shall be conclusive. Provided however, that before this franchise may be terminated and canceled under this section, the franchisee must be provided with an opportunity to be heard before the governing authority. 
(c)  Upon such a termination, the governing authority, within its discretion, may adopt such temporary measures as deemed necessary to continue to provide these waste collection, transportation, and disposal services and as otherwise is deemed necessary to protect the public health, welfare, and safety until such time as a new franchise can be established. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-7. - Participation required. 
Except where provided otherwise in this chapter, all single-family dwellings within the city are required to comply with this chapter and may utilize only the services of the franchisee for the collection, transportation, and disposal of any solid waste. Exempt from this requirement of participation are unoccupied single-family dwellings, defined as a single-family dwelling that has been unoccupied continuously for a period of not less 60 days. Satisfactory proof must be provided to the city by the person wishing to claim this exemption. Should the city determine that false, fraudulent, or misleading information has been provided in an effort to utilize the exemption provided in this provision, then the owner of the property shall be assessed and required to pay all solid waste charges imposed by this chapter as if the property had been occupied for the full extent of the claimed period of unoccupancy. This assessment shall also be a charge and lien against the real property for which said fee is charged and the owner or owners thereof, superior to all other liens except liens for taxes or other assessments. In addition to any other applicable law, the owner of the property may also be fined as provided for in section 26-12. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-8. - Pre-collection practices. 
It shall be the duty of the occupant or owner of any residential premises to keep all refuse pending collection and disposal as follows: 
(1)  Each residence shall be provided by the franchisee with one 90-gallon roll-a-way poly-cart (hereinafter "cart"), or a smaller roll-a-way cart if requested by the customer as well as such container(s) as necessary for purposes of storing items subject to recycling. All containers shall be durable, watertight, nonabsorbent, rust-resistant, rodent-proof, and easily cleanable. Each cart shall be equipped with handles and tightly fitted covers. Carts and containers that do not conform to these specifications or which have defects causing waste to be scattered upon the ground during collection or which hamper or injure the persons collecting the refuse shall be promptly replace. All refuse to be collected shall be free from liquid and placed in water tight plastic bags and the top secured and placed within the cart or recycling container(s) provided for each residence. All carts and recycling containers shall be kept clean and free of accumulated refuse or wastes and shall be treated with an effective insecticide if necessary to prevent the creation of a nuisance. 
(2)  The franchisee shall distribute to all customers written instructions on collection practices and requirements. 
(3)  Each owner shall prevent the continued, excessive and unsightly accumulation of refuse upon the property occupied by him or public thoroughfares adjoining his property. 
(4)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to place or cause to be placed in any refuse container for collection any acid, explosive material, inflammable product, toxic waste, medical or quarantined waste products or any other dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. 
(5)  The disposal of wearing, bedding or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed will be at additional expense to the resident. Such refuse should not be placed inside the cart for routine collection. The resident should contact the franchisee and arrange for special collection of these materials. 
(6)  Ashes shall be placed and maintained in separate containers. It shall be the responsibility of the customer to ascertain that all ashes are cool and that no hot coals remain. 
(7)  Yard waste or trimmings will be at additional expense to the resident and subject to the requirements of the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-9. - Storing refuse. 
(a)  No person shall place any refuse in any street, alley, or other public place, or upon any private property whether owned by such person or not, within the city except it be in proper containers for collection or under express approval granted by the franchisee. Nor shall any person throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water. 
(b)  Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse on any premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of refuse within 30 days of the effective date of this chapter shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  No person shall cast, place, sweep, or deposit anywhere within the city any refuse in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway, or other public place or into any occupied premises within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-10. - Collection practices. 
(a)  Refuse accumulated by residents shall be collected at curbside once each week. The day of collection shall be established by mutual agreement of the city and the franchisee. The franchisee shall observe three annual holidays. They are as follows: New Year's Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. Should one of these holidays fall on a collection day, the collection day shall be the following day. 
(b)  There shall be no collections before 7:00 a.m. or after sunset. 
(c)  The franchisee will provide routine maintenance or replacement of carts and recycling containers due to reasonable wear and tear. The customer shall be responsible for payment for any cart or recycling container which must be replaced as a result of abuse, neglect, loss, or theft. 
(d)  The Franchisee should attempt to handle missed pick ups on the same day, if reported by 2:00 p.m. All missed pick ups shall be corrected within 24 hours. 
(e)  Carts and recycle containers shall be placed at curbside by 7:00 a.m. on scheduled pick up days. Carts and recycle containers shall not be placed curbside more than 12 hours prior to the regularly scheduled pick up day and shall be removed within 12 hours following the regularly scheduled pick up day. Carts and recycle containers shall be placed within 15 feet of the curb or edge of the payment/asphalt of the street or alley and shall be accessible to the side of the street or alley from which the collection is made. However, carts and recycle containers shall not be placed in or on the surface of the roadway, street or alley. 
(f)  Persons who are unable to place their cart or recycle containers at curbside due to physical handicaps may apply to the city for an exemption and, if approved, may receive back door service at their residence at the same monthly rate for curbside service. All persons residing within said residence must be physically handicapped and approved by the city before this service is provided. 
(Ord. No. 2013-7, § 1(Exh. A), 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 26A-11. - Fees charged for services provided. 
(a)  The city shall have the power, right and authority to assess, levy, collect and enforce monthly a solid waste collection, transportation, and disposal assessment (hereinafter "sanitation assessment") in such amount or amounts as provided from time to time by resolution of the governing authority as well as a deposit and administrative fee to be paid by those required to participate in the solid waste program established by this chapter, such fees to be paid in connection with and prior to the commencement of solid waste collection, transportation and disposal services to defray the reasonable costs incurred by the city in establishing and operating this program. The monthly assessment and the deposit and administrative fee shall be charged to the occupant of the residential property being serviced. This monthly assessment as well as the deposit and administrative fee shall also be a charge and lien against the real property for which said fee was charged and the owner or owners thereof, superior to all other liens except liens for taxes or other assessments. 
(b)  The governing authority may in its discretion establish a separate, reduced monthly charge for customers age 65 or older. 
(c)  Subject to the approval of the governing authority, the city manager and/or his designee is directed to establish guidelines for a reduced monthly charge or waiver of any fee prescribed by this chapter for those who can demonstrate a financial hardship. 
(d)  A ten percent penalty shall be assessed on all accounts considered delinquent. 
(e)  All accounts shall be considered delinquent if not paid by the fifteenth day of the month in which the monthly statement is issued. All delinquent accounts shall be assessed a ten percent penalty and are subject to stoppage of service without notice. If a delinquent account is not paid within 30 days, all refuse collection may cease for that account. Service shall be resumed thereafter only on payment of the accumulated fees for the period of collection and of the period of non-collection plus penalties. Additionally, the city shall have the right to collect a deposit equal to two months of service fees before reestablishing sanitation collection at any property on which sanitation collection was discontinued due to nonpayment or late payment of the fee required by this chapter.
